questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy comes to the physician because of body aches and sore throat for 1 week. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He lives with his parents; they recently adopted a cat from an animal shelter. He is sexually active with one female partner, and they use condoms consistently. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. The pharynx is red and swollen. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
15 g/dL


Leukocyte count
11,500/mm3



 Segmented neutrophils
48%


 Band forms
2%


 Basophils
0.5%


 Eosinophils
1%


 Lymphocytes

45%


 Monocytes
3.5%


When the patient's serum is added to a sample of horse erythrocytes, the cells aggregate together. Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus is transmitted via saliva and respiratory secretions and can cause infectious mononucleosis (IM). This condition typically affects young adults and classically manifests with fever, myalgia, pharyngitis, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and lymphocytosis as seen in this patient. Additional manifestations include tonsillitis, palatal petechiae, and splenomegaly. Infectious mononucleosis can be diagnosed clinically, but laboratory studies (e.g., EBV serology) are often performed. Supportive laboratory studies include a CBC with differential and monospot (heterophile antibody) test. Peripheral blood smear of patients with IM typically shows lymphocytosis with > 10% atypical lymphocytes. Management includes symptomatic treatment (e.g., fluids, analgesics, antipyretics) and avoidance of physical activity that can trigger splenic rupture for at least 3 weeks after the onset of symptoms.

Although the monospot test is commonly used to support the diagnosis of IM, this test is nonspecific and may be false positive (e.g., in patients with previous infection) and false negative (e.g., in patients tested within 1 week of symptom onset).

B) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus infection is typically asymptomatic but can manifest with fever and myalgia. Pharyngitis, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and lymphocytosis are less common manifestations. In addition, cytomegalovirus infection does not result in a positive heterophile antibody test.

C) INCORRECT:

Though acute human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is often asymptomatic, it can cause fever, myalgia, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy. Acute HIV infection can also uncommonly cause a positive heterophile antibody test. However, this patient has no reported risk factors for acquiring HIV infection (e.g., multiple sexual partners, inconsistent use of condoms). Moreover, unlike this patient who has a leukocytosis, patients with acute HIV infection typically have an early decrease in leukocyte and lymphocyte count.

D) INCORRECT:

Group A streptococci (GAS) infection typically causes fever, pharyngitis, and anterior (not posterior) cervical lymphadenopathy but does not commonly cause myalgia or lymphocytosis. In addition, this patient does not have other manifestations of GAS infection such as nausea and vomiting, or an erythematous, sandpaper-like rash. Moreover, GAS infection does not result in a positive heterophile antibody test.

E) INCORRECT:

Influenza infection is common and typically causes fever, myalgia, pharyngitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Leukocyte count in patients with this infection is often normal or decreased in the early stage and increased in later stages. However, influenza infection does not result in a positive heterophile antibody test.

F) INCORRECT:

In immunocompetent individuals, Toxoplasma gondii infection is typically asymptomatic but can manifest with fever, myalgia, pharyngitis, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Leukocyte count in patients with this infection is often normal but can be elevated. Transmission of T. gondii occurs via ingestion of oocysts from cat feces or cysts in the meat of infected animals. This patient, who has a new cat at home, has an increased risk of developing T. gondii infection. However, this infection does not result in a positive heterophile antibody test.
questions.hint: This patient has an infection that has induced lymphocytes to produce antibodies that can react to antigens from unrelated species. This phenomenon results in the aggregation of horse erythrocytes when exposed to his serum (i.e., a positive heterophile antibody test).

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician with a 4-day history of sore throat and mild fever. He is on the varsity soccer team at his high school, but has been unable to go to practice for the last few days because he has been very tired and is easily exhausted. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He appears weak and lethargic. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg. Examination shows enlarged, erythematous, and exudative tonsils; posterior cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.5 g/dL and leukocyte count is 11,200/mm3 with 48% lymphocytes. A heterophile antibody test is positive. In addition to supportive therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Write a medical note that excuses the patient from soccer practice
Recommend avoiding public places and social gatherings
Measure serum anti-viral capsid antigen antibody concentration

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A common finding in patients with IM is splenomegaly, which increases the risk of splenic rupture. Although this patient's abdominal examination shows no abnormalities, the spleen may still be or become enlarged. Since splenic rupture is most likely to occur 2–21 days after symptom onset, patients should avoid strenuous physical activity (e.g., soccer) for at least 3 weeks after initial symptoms develop and avoid contact sports (e.g., football, wrestling) for at least 4 weeks. Treatment of IM is mainly symptomatic and involves antipyretic and analgesic therapy (e.g., acetaminophen).

B) INCORRECT:

IM spreads via bodily fluids such as saliva. Unless patients have immediate contact with other individuals such as from kissing or sharing objects that have been contaminated with another person's bodily fluids (e.g., toothbrush, drinking glass), infection is unlikely. A recommendation to avoid public places and gatherings is therefore not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is indicated for bacterial tonsillitis and pharyngitis, both of which can present with fever, sore throat, enlarged tonsils with exudates, and/or cervical lymphadenopathy. However, lymphocytosis and a positive heterophile antibody test indicate EBV infection. Patients with EBV infection are often mistakenly treated with aminopenicillins because IM presents similarly to streptococcal pharyngitis and tonsilitis and these conditions are also typically diagnosed clinically. Additionally, rapid GAS antigen detection tests (rapid strep tests) can be positive in IM due to asymptomatic colonization of the pharynx with group A beta-hemolytic streptococci. Administering aminopenicillin to patients with IM should be avoided to prevent the potential complication of a pruritic, macular erythematous rash developing 5–9 days later.

D) INCORRECT:

Steroids are not recommended for routine use in IM treatment. They may be considered in complicated disease courses, e.g. in patients with severe airway obstruction, fulminant liver failure, or autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, none of which are seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is an antiviral agent used to treat infections with herpes simplex virus (HSV) and varicella zoster virus (VZV). It is not indicated for infections with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV; the cause of infectious mononucleosis), despite also belonging to the human herpesvirus family. HSV and VZV infections are commonly associated with a characteristic vesicular eruptions (e.g., herpetic gingivostomatitis, chickenpox, respectively) but not IM.

Patients with infectious mononucleosis may also present with a rash. However, the rash is usually maculopapular and most commonly occurs following antibiotic treatment with aminopenicillins (e.g., ampicillin, amoxicillin).

F) INCORRECT:

Antiviral capsid antigen antibodies (anti-VCA) are used in the diagnosis of IM. However, testing for anti-VCA is only indicated if IM is suspected but the heterophile agglutination test is negative. Considering that the heterophile antibody test has a specificity of nearly 100% for EBV infection, no further testing is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

In acute infection, both anti-VCA IgM and anti-VCA IgG can usually be found. The finding of IgG VCA antibodies in the absence if IgM VCA antibodies suggests past infection.

G) INCORRECT:

Foscarnet is an antiviral agent used in the treatment of cytomegalovirus and herpes simplex virus infections. While the majority of mononucleosis syndromes are caused by Epstein-Barr virus, infection with CMV accounts for ∼ 7% of cases. However, in CMV mononucleosis, symptoms are often milder, pharyngitis/tonsillitis are typically absent, and the heterophile antibody test is negative.
questions.hint: Fever, fatigue, exudative tonsillitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, lymphocytosis, and a positive heterophile antibody test in an adolescent indicate infectious mononucleosis (IM).

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a sore throat and fevers for the past 2 weeks. She has been feeling lethargic and is unable to attend school. She has a history of multiple episodes of streptococcal pharyngitis treated with amoxicillin. She immigrated with her family to the United States from China 10 years ago. She appears thin. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows pharyngeal erythema and enlarged tonsils with exudates and palatal petechiae. There is cervical lymphadenopathy. The spleen is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12 g/dL, leukocyte count is 14,100/mm3 with 54% lymphocytes (12% atypical lymphocytes), and platelet count is 280,000/mm3. A heterophile agglutination test is positive. This patient’s diagnosis puts her at increased risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever may occur as a complication of group A streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis and typically affects individuals 5–15 years of age within 1–5 weeks of infection. Although this patient has a sore throat, pharyngeal erythema, enlarged tonsils, cervical lymphadenopathy, and a history of recurrent streptococcal pharyngitis, she also presents with splenomegaly and has a positive heterophile agglutination test, which indicates IM.

B) INCORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma is caused by the human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), not EBV (human herpesvirus 4, HHV-4), and typically occurs in individuals with HIV infection. While acute HIV infection and IM are difficult to distinguish clinically, this patient's pharyngeal erythema and exudative enlarged tonsils favor a diagnosis of IM, which is further supported by a positive heterophile agglutination test.

C) CORRECT:

EBV infection is associated with the development of multiple malignancies, including nasopharyngeal carcinoma, Burkitt lymphoma, and Hodgkin lymphoma. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma typically manifests with epistaxis, painless cervical lymphadenopathy, and recurrent otitis media.

D) INCORRECT:

Necrotizing retinitis is a potential complication of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, particularly for immunocompromised individuals (e.g., patients with HIV infection, posttransplantation). CMV infection can cause a mononucleosis-like syndrome (CMV mononucleosis), which can also manifest with fever, malaise, fatigue, sore throat, cervical lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and lymphocytosis. However, in CMV mononucleosis, a heterophile agglutination test is typically negative.

E) INCORRECT:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis may occur as a complication of group A streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis and typically manifests 1–3 weeks following infection. Although this patient has a sore throat, pharyngeal erythema, enlarged tonsils, cervical lymphadenopathy, and a history of recurrent streptococcal pharyngitis, she also presents with splenomegaly and has a positive heterophile agglutination test, which indicates IM.
questions.hint: Fever, fatigue, exudative tonsillitis with palatal petechiae, cervical lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, lymphocytosis, and a positive heterophile agglutination test in an adolescent indicates infectious mononucleosis (IM) due to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of fever, fatigue, and a sore throat for 12 days. He was prescribed amoxicillin at another clinic and now has a diffuse rash all over his body. He was treated for gonorrhea one year ago. He has multiple sexual partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears lethargic and thin. His BMI is 19 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse 94/min, blood pressure 106/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a morbilliform rash over his extremities. Oropharyngeal examination shows tonsillar enlargement and erythema with exudates. Tender cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Abdominal examination shows mild splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14 g/dL


Leukocyte count
13,200/mm3



Platelet count
160,000/mm3



Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A throat swab culture is indicated for streptococcal pharyngitis. Although the symptoms of fever, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy may suggest pharyngitis due to Streptococcus, the maculopapular rash, splenomegaly, and lack of improvement with antibiotics make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

The presence of anti-CMV IgM would indicate an acute cytomegalovirus infection, which can also present with fever, fatigue, and a sore throat. Lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly are possible, but rare. This constellation of symptoms is more likely the result of another diagnosis, meaning a different step is indicated at this time. However, if that step shows negative results, measuring serum anti-CMV IgM levels would be indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

The enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is a technique used for the screening of several diseases, including HIV. This patient has some signs of primary HIV infection (fever, sore throat, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, rash) and risk factors for HIV transmission (multiple sexual partners, inconsistent condom use), but splenomegaly, tonsillar exudates, and lack of diarrhea make another diagnosis more likely.

D) CORRECT:

Fever, exudative tonsillitis, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and leukocytosis are all indicative of infectious mononucleosis (IM), which is caused by an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. Although IM itself does not usually cause a rash, a morbilliform rash commonly occurs in patients with this condition who are mistakenly administered an aminopenicillin with the intent of treating a bacterial infection (e.g., streptococcal pharyngitis, which also manifests with fever, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy). The diagnosis of IM is typically clinical but EBV serology is the most reliable laboratory study. Anti-VCA IgM antibodies alone are sufficient to diagnose acute infection. A positive heterophile agglutination test (monospot test) can support the diagnosis but carries a high risk of false positive and false negative results and is therefore not the test of choice.

E) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry is a technique employed for evaluation of patients with lymphocytosis, including those suspected of leukemia or lymphoma. Although blood cancers often present with lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, lymphocytosis, and low body weight (e.g., BMI of 19), the sudden onset of fever, sore throat, tender lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar exudates in this patient indicates an active infection. Additionally, a morbilliform rash (following amoxicillin intake) would not be expected.
questions.hint: A morbilliform rash appearing after the administration of an aminopenicillin for a sore throat is typical for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of recurring fever and night sweats. The fevers persist for 7 to 10 days and then subside completely for about a week before returning again. During the past 6 months, has had a 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss and has also noticed painless lumps on his neck that have gradually increased in size. Two years ago, he had a severe sore throat and fever, which was diagnosed as infectious mononucleosis. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. He does not drink alcohol. His job involves monthly international travel to Asia and Africa. He takes no medications. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows enlarged, nontender, fixed cervical lymph nodes on each side of the neck. A photomicrograph from a biopsy of a cervical lymph node is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: IgG and IgM antibodies against a viral capsid antigen
Acid fast bacilli in the sputum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A proliferation of monomorphic lymphocytic cells is a characteristic feature of some non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs), in contrast to the heterogeneous morphology of classic Hodgkin lymphoma. NHLs can cause lymphadenopathy and B symptoms but histopathology is unlikely to show Reed-Sternberg cells. Additionally, NHLs often cause extranodal disease, most commonly involving the gastrointestinal tract, skin, thyroid, and CNS, but the patient has no complaints relating to any of these organs.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, i.e., infectious mononucleosis (IM), would result in the presence of both IgG and IgM antibodies against the EBV-associated viral capsid antigen (VCA). Because of this patient's past IM, he would test positive for IgG anti-VCA antibodies but IgM anti-VCA antibodies typically disappear 3 months after the primary EBV infection.

C) CORRECT:

Lymph node biopsies in cases of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) can show Reed-Sternberg cells, which are CD15/30-positive, polynuclear giant cells that originate from B cells. Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for HL and confirm the diagnosis.

Past primary infection with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), i.e., infectious mononucleosis, is a risk factor for HL. The most common histological types of EBV-associated HL are mixed cellularity HL and lymphocyte-depleted HL, and the median time to the onset of EBV-associated HL is approx. 3 years after the primary infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Auer rods on a peripheral smear are characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). AML causes bone marrow failure, resulting in anemia and an increased risk of bleeding and infections. Although the fever in this patient could indicate an infection, he lacks pallor and petechiae. Additionally, lymphadenopathy is not a typical feature of AML, and Reed-Sternberg cells would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Extreme leukocytosis (> 500,000/μL) is typical in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), a disease that causes B symptoms. However, lymphadenopathy is not a typical initial finding in CML, and the patient does not have splenomegaly, another characteristic finding in CML. CML would also not cause Reed-Sternberg cells.

F) INCORRECT:

The presence of acid-fast bacilli in the sputum is consistent with pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). Active pulmonary TB can cause B symptoms, and the incidence of TB is high in Africa and Asia, where this patient frequently travels. However, the most important finding in active pulmonary TB would be a productive cough and dyspnea, and histopathology would show caseating granulomas. Reed-Sternberg cells would not be expected.
questions.hint: Regional nontender lymphadenopathy, B symptoms with a Pel-Ebstein fever pattern, and the lymph node biopsy finding of typical Reed-Sternberg cells on an inflammatory background indicate a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A previously healthy 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of fever, fatigue, and a sore throat for 8 days. She also has a diffuse rash that started yesterday. Three days ago, she took amoxicillin that she had at home. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse 99/min, blood pressure 106/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a morbilliform rash over her trunk and extremities. Oropharyngeal examination shows tonsillar enlargement and erythema with exudates. Tender cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy are present. Abdominal examination shows mild splenomegaly. A peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytosis with > 10% atypical lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is a technique used for the screening of several diseases, including HIV. This patient has some signs of primary HIV infection (fever, sore throat, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, rash) and risk factors for HIV transmission (multiple sexual partners, inconsistent condom use), but splenomegaly, tonsillar exudates, and lack of diarrhea make another diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry is a technique employed for evaluation of patients with lymphocytosis, including those suspected of leukemia or lymphoma. Although blood cancers often present with lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, lymphocytosis, and fatigue, the sudden onset of fever, sore throat, tender lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar exudates in this patient indicates an active infection. Additionally, a morbilliform rash following amoxicillin intake would not be expected.
Image Description:

Flow cytometry is a technique for the identification, quantification, and sorting of single cells in a cell suspension, often with the use of fluorescent-tagged antibodies to detect the presence of specific target antigens (as illustrated here).

Inside the nozzle, a fluid (sheath fluid) focuses the cells into a narrow stream, causing them to pass across the laser beam in single file. As the laser hits each cell, the light scattered varies in accordance with its size, shape, and intracellular and cell surface molecules. Cells containing the target antigen also have the fluorescent-tagged antibody bound to them, which emits light of a specific wavelength when activated by the laser beam (yellow and blue, in this image).
A detector directly opposite the laser beam measures the amount of forward scatter, and detectors placed perpendicular to the laser beam measure side scatter and fluorescence.

The collected data can then be plotted as a histogram (yellow graph and blue graph) or a scatter plot (bottom right graph). Histograms measure a single parameter, displaying a large number of events (cells) as a spike. Scatter plots measure two parameters simultaneously, representing each event (cell) as a single point and clustering events with similar fluorescence intensities. In the case illustrated, the gray cells do not possess the target antigens and are marked as events at low fluorescence intensity on both axes in the scatter plot. By contrast, green cells possess two target antigens and are represented as high fluorescence intensity events on both axes.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of anti-CMV IgM would indicate an acute cytomegalovirus infection, which can also present with fever, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and a sore throat, as seen in this patient. However, splenomegaly and a morbilliform rash after administration of an aminopenicillin are not consistent with a CMV infection.

D) INCORRECT:

A throat swab culture is indicated for streptococcal pharyngitis. Although the symptoms of fever, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy may suggest pharyngitis due to Streptococcus, the maculopapular rash and splenomegaly make this diagnosis unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Fever, exudative tonsillitis, (generalized) lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and leukocytosis are all indicative of infectious mononucleosis (IM), which is caused by an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. The atypical lymphocytes on this patient's peripheral blood smear are reactive CD8+ cytotoxic T cells. The diagnosis of IM is typically clinical but EBV serology is the most reliable laboratory study. Anti-VCA IgM antibodies alone are sufficient to diagnose acute infection. A positive heterophile agglutination test (monospot test) can support the diagnosis but carries a high risk of false positive and false negative results and is therefore not the test of choice. Although IM itself does not usually cause a rash, a morbilliform rash commonly occurs in patients with this condition who are mistakenly administered an aminopenicillin with the intent of treating a bacterial infection (e.g., streptococcal pharyngitis, which also manifests with fever, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy).
questions.hint: This 16-year-old girl with fatigue, sore throat, mild splenomegaly, and a history of rash after administration of amoxicillin is likely suffering from a viral infection common in this age group.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-week history of fever, fatigue, and throat pain. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Oral examination shows the findings in the photograph. A peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. A heterophile antibody test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin therapy is indicated for tonsillopharyngitis caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS). GAS tonsillopharyngitis typically manifests with fever, throat pain, and cervical lymphadenopathy. However, it does not cause lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes or a positive heterophile antibody test. Oral amoxicillin therapy is not used to treat Epstein-Barr virus infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Antiretroviral therapy is primarily used to treat human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. Acute HIV infection can manifest with fever, fatigue, throat pain, and lymphadenopathy and can rarely cause a positive heterophile antibody test. However, it does not cause lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of acute HIV infection, such as headache, weight loss, myalgias, arthralgias, an exanthematous rash, nausea, diarrhea, and lymphocytopenia. Antiretroviral therapy is not used to treat Epstein-Barr virus infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone marrow biopsy is used to evaluate various hematologic conditions, including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), which typically manifests with fever, fatigue, and lymphadenopathy and can rarely cause a positive heterophile antibody test. However, it does not cause throat pain, the exudates seen in the photograph, or lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. In addition, this patient lacks other typical findings of ALL, such as weight loss, bone pain, thrombocytopenia, and lymphoblasts on a peripheral blood smear. Bone marrow biopsy does not have a role in the evaluation or management of Epstein-Barr virus infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Diphtheria antitoxin and antibiotics (e.g., penicillin G) are used to treat diphtheria, an infectious disease caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Respiratory diphtheria typically involves the tonsillopharyngeal area and manifests with fever, fatigue, throat pain, cervical lymphadenopathy, and white-gray pseudomembranes on the tonsils (caused by bacteria, epithelial cells, and inflammatory cells). However, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of respiratory diphtheria, including swelling of the anterior neck and difficulty breathing. Moreover, this condition is very rare due to widespread immunization (e.g., with DTaP).

E) CORRECT:

This patient has infectious mononucleosis (IM), a condition caused by Epstein-Barr virus. IM is most common among adolescents and typically manifests with fever, fatigue, throat pain, tonsillopharyngitis, bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, and lymphocytosis with atypical lymphocytes. Although nonspecific, a positive heterophile antibody test supports the diagnosis. Treatment for IM is mainly supportive (e.g., fluids, antipyretics, analgesics). Approximately 50% of patients with IM develop splenomegaly, which increases the risk of splenic rupture, a rare but life-threatening complication. Though more than half of cases of splenic rupture occur spontaneously, patients with IM should avoid strenuous physical activity that may precipitate this complication (e.g., contact sports) for at least 4 weeks after the initial onset of symptoms.

Administering amoxicillin or ampicillin to patients with infectious mononucleosis (e.g., if they were thought to have streptococcal pharyngitis) can precipitate a maculopapular rash.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient has infectious mononucleosis, a condition caused by Epstein-Barr virus. Infectious mononucleosis spreads primarily through salivary secretions (e.g., via kissing or contamination of objects with saliva); patients with this condition do not need to avoid crowded places.
questions.hint: The photograph shows massively enlarged, erythematous tonsils that are covered with purulent, white-gray exudates. This form of tonsillopharyngitis is caused by Epstein-Barr virus.

questions.text: A previously healthy 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever, fatigue, myalgia, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. He works as a tour guide but has been unable to go to work for the last few days because he is easily exhausted. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Examination of the neck and oropharynx shows tender cervical lymphadenopathy and erythematous, swollen tonsils with white exudates. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin and the spleen is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.2 g/dL and his leukocyte count is 16,400/mm3. A blood smear shows atypical lymphocytosis. A heterophile antibody test is positive. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Splenic rupture secondary to splenomegaly is a rare but severe complication of IM. Since splenic rupture is most likely to occur 2–21 days after symptom onset, patients should avoid physical activity for at least 21 days after initial symptoms develop and avoid contact sports (e.g., football, wrestling) for at least 4 weeks. If patients have signs of potential splenic rupture (e.g., left upper quadrant pain, Kehr sign), imaging with ultrasound or CT is indicated. The management of IM-associated splenic rupture is the same as that for traumatic splenic rupture and depends on the extent of the injury: Hemodynamically stable patients with low-grade splenic lesions can often be treated conservatively (observation and symptomatic treatment) whereas hemodynamically unstable patients or those with high-grade splenic lesions require surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Burkitt lymphoma (BL) is an aggressive B-cell lymphoma that can develop following EBV infection. However, BL is more common in children and is most prevalent in individuals living in equatorial Africa and South America. A different complication is much more likely to occur in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Glomerulonephritis can develop as a result of group A streptococcal pharyngitis, which manifests with fever, sore throat, dysphagia, and tonsillar exudates, all of which are seen here. However, splenomegaly and a positive heterophile antibody test indicate IM, which does not lead to glomerulonephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

EBV infection is associated with several malignancies such as Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It is not, however, associated with acute lymphocytic leukemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Oropharyngeal carcinoma is associated with human papillomavirus infection (HPV types 16, 17, 31, and 33), not IM. IM is caused by EBV infection, which is associated with an increased risk of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, not oropharyngeal carcinoma.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, fatigue, myalgia, tonsillitis, tender cervical lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and leukocytosis with atypical lymphocytosis are typical features of infectious mononucleosis (IM), which is caused by EBV infection. A positive heterophile antibody test (monospot test) supports the diagnosis.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old young woman reports a 4-day history of sore throat and generalized malaise. She is up to date with all of her vaccinations, including Covid-19. She is not sexually active and says she has not used illicit drugs.
She has a temperature of 38.9°C, pharyngeal erythema, white-grey tonsillar exudates, and tender posterior cervical lymph nodes approximately 1.0 cm in diameter. No splenomegaly is present.
Initial laboratory testing is notable for a leukocyte count of 5000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with 13% atypical lymphocytes present on peripheral-blood smear.
Infectious workup reveals negative results for SARS-CoV-2, a negative heterophile antibody (Monospot) test and a negative rapid antigen test for group A Streptococcus.
Which one of the tests is most likely to be diagnostic in this case?

choices.text: Testing for immunoglobulin M and immunoglobulin G antibodies against Epstein-Barr viral capsid antigen
Serum testing for cytomegalovirus immunoglobulin G
Bacterial throat culture for Arcanobacterium haemolyticum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A rapid influenza antigen test is not helpful because although influenza can cause fever, sore throat, and malaise, it does not typically cause lymphadenopathy and atypical lymphocytosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum cytomegalovirus IgG testing or HIV antibody testing would not be helpful because, although acute infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV) and HIV should be considered in this scenario, these tests may not be positive in the acute phase of these infections. HIV RNA testing should be performed if acute HIV infection is suspected.

C) CORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis, an acute infection typically caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), is most common among adolescents and young adults. Symptoms typically include malaise, fever, pharyngitis, bilateral tender cervical lymphadenopathy, and sometimes splenomegaly. Patients suspected of having infectious mononucleosis should undergo testing for EBV with heterophile antibody (Monospot) testing. Because the Monospot test can be negative in up to 25% of patients within the first week of infection, it should be followed by repeat Monospot testing or EBV-specific serologic testing, such as immunoglobulin (Ig) M and IgG antibodies against Epstein-Barr viral capsid antigen. In acute EBV mononucleosis, the viral capsid antigen IgM is positive.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test for a young woman with features of infectious mononucleosis but a negative heterophile antibody (Monospot) test is testing for immunoglobulin M and immunoglobulin G antibodies against Epstein-Barr viral capsid antigen.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum cytomegalovirus IgG testing or HIV antibody testing would not be helpful because, although acute infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV) and HIV should be considered in this scenario, these tests may not be positive in the acute phase of these infections. When acute CMV infection is suspected, testing for IgM antibody or CMV DNA should be performed.

E) INCORRECT:

Although Arcanobacterium haemolyticum infection can cause pharyngitis in young adults, it would not be expected to manifest with atypical lymphocytosis.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man presents 7 days after being evaluated for a 3-day history of severe sore throat. At the previous visit, rapid tests for streptococcal infection and SARS-CoV-2 were negative, and a 5-day course of azithromycin was provided. Since that visit, he continues to experience severe sore throat and pain with swallowing, despite having completed the course of antibiotics. He now reports intermittent fever, with temperatures as high as 38.3°C, but no cough or nasal congestion.
On physical examination, his temperature is 38.0°C. He has marked pharyngeal erythema and edematous, erythematous tonsils with exudates. There is no evidence of peritonsillar abscess or localized neck pain. He has posterior cervical adenopathy, mild tenderness to deep abdominal palpation under the left anterior rib cage, and splenomegaly.
His leukocyte count is 5000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with 13% atypical lymphocytes. Repeat testing for SARS-CoV-2 using a polymerase chain-reaction assay is negative. A heterophile antibody test (Monospot) is negative, and a chest radiograph is normal.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antistreptolysin O antibody testing can be helpful to evaluate whether a patient has had a recent infection with S. pyogenes, but it is not a useful test in the acute setting of pharyngitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus) can cause pharyngitis in adolescents and young adults, it would not be expected to manifest with atypical lymphocytosis. In addition, this patient’s rapid test for streptococcal infection was negative, and this test has an excellent negative predictive value, so a bacterial throat culture would not be useful.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s constellation of symptoms is highly suspicious for infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), but his heterophile antibody (Monospot) test was negative. Given that Monospot testing can produce false-negative results early in the course of illness, the most appropriate next step is to either repeat the Monospot test or perform EBV-specific serologic testing, such as for immunoglobulin (Ig) M and IgG antibodies against Epstein-Barr viral capsid antigen (VCA) and for antibodies against Epstein-Barr nuclear antigen (EBNA).

In acute EBV mononucleosis, the VCA IgM is positive. Antibodies to EBV early antigen (EA) and VCA appear early in acute infection, whereas antibodies to EBNA do not develop until 2 to 3 months after onset of infection.

Key learning point: The test results most likely to reveal a diagnosis of acute Epstein-Barr virus infection are positive serum immunoglobulin M antibodies against Epstein-Barr viral capsid antigen and absence of antibodies against Epstein-Barr nuclear antigen.

D) INCORRECT:

Although acute infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV) should be considered in this clinical scenario, acute CMV infection is best diagnosed serologically with IgM antibody or with CMV DNA, not with a viral throat culture.

E) INCORRECT:

Empiric treatment with a different antibiotic is not indicated in this case. The patient already received azithromycin with no improvement. Additional antibiotics would be unnecessary and could result in a cutaneous eruption, as has been reported to occur commonly in patients with EBV infection who receive amoxicillin.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 19-year-old man presents with a 4-day history of fever, headache, sore throat, and malaise. He has not been able to tolerate solid foods but has been drinking liquids without difficulty. He is up to date on all vaccinations, including Covid-19.
His temperature is 39.5°C, his heart rate is 90 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, his blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 98% while he breathes ambient air. He is awake and oriented but appears tired.
He has pharyngeal edema and erythema with bilateral tonsillar exudates and prominent posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. He can move his neck fully in all directions and does not have trismus, uvular deviation, stridor, or respiratory distress. His mucous membranes are moist, and he has brisk capillary refill. His abdomen is soft and nondistended, but his spleen tip is palpable 2 cm below the costal margin.
Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative, a throat swab rapid streptococcal antigen test is negative, and a culture is incubating.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Provide supportive care with antipyretics and oral hydration
Prescribe a course of oral acyclovir
Initiate a course of oral amoxicillin while awaiting the throat cultures
Recommend bed rest until the symptoms resolve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment with glucocorticoids such as prednisone remains controversial. There is no evidence to support their routine use, but they may be considered in severe cases, especially when there is concern for upper airway obstruction.

B) CORRECT:

The combination of fever, exudative pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, malaise, and splenomegaly is consistent with infectious mononucleosis, likely secondary to infection with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). Although not always necessary, a heterophile antibody test, EBV serology, or the presence of atypical lymphocytes on a peripheral smear can be used to support the diagnosis.

Given that this patient is well hydrated on examination and has no evidence of airway compromise, supportive care is the most appropriate management. Supportive care recommendations generally include rest, fluids, and pain and fever control with acetaminophen or nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for uncomplicated infectious mononucleosis is supportive care.

C) INCORRECT:

Although acyclovir may slow viral replication in vitro, it has not demonstrated clinical efficacy in the treatment of EBV-related infectious mononucleosis and is not recommended in this setting.

D) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin or other antibiotics are not necessary because mononucleosis is a viral infection. In patients with infectious mononucleosis due to EBV, treatment with amoxicillin can lead to a nonallergic morbilliform rash.

E) INCORRECT:

Given the risk of splenic rupture, patients with infectious mononucleosis should avoid contact sports until they have fully recovered and the spleen is no longer palpable, but strict bed rest is unnecessary.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man who plays college lacrosse presents with a one-week history of malaise, headache, fever, and sore throat that have made it impossible for him to participate in lacrosse practice.
He has a fever of 38.9°C, pharyngeal erythema and exudates, and tender posterior cervical adenopathy. His spleen is not palpable.
He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A heterophile antibody latex agglutination and Epstein-Barr virus viral capsid antigen immunoglobulin M and immunoglobulin G are positive.
Which one of the following criteria best determines when this athlete is likely to be able to safely return to full activity, including sports, assuming resolution of symptoms?

choices.text: An Epstein-Barr virus viral capsid antigen immunoglobulin M test is negative
Seven weeks elapse after the onset of symptoms
Three weeks elapse after the onset of symptoms
An abdominal ultrasound confirms the absence of splenomegaly
Ten days elapse after the onset of symptoms

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Repeat laboratory assessment of the Epstein-Barr virus viral capsid antigen immunoglobulin M test is not used to guide return-to-play decisions.

B) INCORRECT:

Splenic ruptures have been reported up to 7 weeks after the onset of symptoms, but the risk of rupture beyond 3 to 4 weeks is very low.

C) CORRECT:

Infectious mononucleosis temporarily increases the risk for splenic rupture in young athletes. Splenomegaly is commonly seen in 50% to 60% of cases, but there is debate about whether the size of the spleen or the infection itself is the cause of the increased risk of splenic rupture. Although avoiding abdominal trauma is advisable during acute infection, half of splenic ruptures in athletes occur without trauma.

There is general consensus that an athlete who is asymptomatic may return to regular activity 3 weeks after the onset of symptoms. This recommendation is based on data showing that the majority of splenic ruptures occur within the first 3 weeks of the illness.

Splenic ruptures have been reported up to 7 weeks after the onset of symptoms, but the risk of rupture beyond 3 to 4 weeks is very low.

Key learning point: In an effort to prevent splenic rupture in the setting of infectious mononucleosis, an athlete should initially be restricted from all physical activity and may return to it when he or she is asymptomatic and 3 weeks have elapsed since the onset of symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasound to assess spleen size is not recommended in determining when an athlete may return to light activity, because spleen size varies widely and no reliable methods can assess whether the spleen size has recently changed.

E) INCORRECT:

There is general consensus that an athlete who is asymptomatic may return to regular activity 3 weeks after the onset of symptoms. This recommendation is based on data showing that the majority of splenic ruptures occur within the first 3 weeks of the illness.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 14-year-old boy presents with a 4-day history of fever, headache, sore throat, and malaise. He has not been able to tolerate solid foods but has been drinking liquids without difficulty. He is up to date on all vaccinations, including Covid-19.

Provide supportive care with antipyretics and oral hydration
Prescribe a course of oral acyclovir

Supportive care recommendations generally include rest, fluids, and pain and fever control with acetaminophen or nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications.

E) INCORRECT:

Although acyclovir may slow viral replication in vitro, it has not demonstrated clinical efficacy in the treatment of EBV-related infectious mononucleosis and is not recommended in this setting.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl who runs for her high school cross-country team presents with a one-week history of malaise, headache, fever, and sore throat that have made it impossible for her to participate in practices.
She has a fever of 38.9°C, pharyngeal erythema and exudates, and tender posterior cervical adenopathy. Her spleen is not palpable.

For individuals involved in strenuous contact sports (e.g., wrestling, gymnastics, football), additional care is warranted, and return to activity should not occur until 5 to 7 weeks from symptom onset.

There is general consensus that an athlete who is asymptomatic may return to regular activity 3 weeks after the onset of symptoms. This recommendation is based on data showing that the majority of splenic ruptures occur within the first 3 weeks of the illness.

Splenomegaly is commonly seen in 50% to 60% of cases, but there is debate about whether the size of the spleen or the infection itself is the cause of the increased risk of splenic rupture. Although avoiding abdominal trauma is advisable during acute infection, half of splenic ruptures in athletes occur without trauma.

There is general consensus that an athlete who is asymptomatic may return to regular activity 3 weeks after the onset of symptoms. This recommendation is based on data showing that the majority of splenic ruptures occur within the first 3 weeks of the illness.

Key learning point: In an effort to prevent splenic rupture in the setting of infectious mononucleosis, an athlete should initially be restricted from all physical activity and may return to it when he or she is asymptomatic and 3 weeks have elapsed since the onset of symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:
